body: Thanks, at this point we can probably add an option to skip `too-few-public-methods` for certain data style classes, such as `namedtuple`, `pydantic` and `dataclasses`.

That sounds great. Note that pydantic comes also with a [dataclass implementation](https://pydantic-docs.helpmanual.io/usage/dataclasses/) that supports validation. It might make sense to look into supporting this as well.
Any updates on this issue? ðŸ™‚
Please set "help wanted" tag to search for someone who can fix this issue

I'm game to take a crack at this, but I'm uncertain if it's acceptable to add the `pydantic` package to the `requirements_test.txt` file for this test? Is there another place I should look for how external test deps are expressed?

We're trying not to add packages to the tests requirements right now. I think at this point it could be a configurable option to add classes that should be ignored by this check. This way we could test with any classes even one we created specifically for the test and easily add other similar classes.

> ... it could be a configurable option to add classes that should be ignored by this check

I like this - something like this?

```
[DESIGN]
exclude-too-few-public-methods=pydantic.*
```
?
Looks great ! How would we handle multiple values ? filter separated by comma, a regex ?
I guess following the existing patterns, it'd be a comma-separated list of module names/prefixes.

issue.title: Add configuration option ``exclude-too-few-public-methods``

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
- [x] Add yourself to CONTRIBUTORS if you are a new contributor.
- [x] Add a ChangeLog entry describing what your PR does.
- [x] If it's a new feature, or an important bug fix, add a What's New entry in
      `doc/whatsnew/<current release.rst>`.
- [x] Write a good description on what the PR does.

## Type of Changes

<!-- Leave the corresponding lines for the applicable type of change: -->

|     | Type                   |
| --- | ---------------------- |
| âœ“   | :sparkles: New feature |

## Description

Add feature to exclude classes from too-few-public-methods

Instead of adding specific packages to an in-code exclusion list,
add a configuration value that allows the end user to set values
for packages/modules and classes to exclude from evaluation.

Closes #3370

issue.title: Pydantic BaseModel raises too-few-public-methods warning

labels.name: Lib specific ðŸ’…
labels.description: This affect the code from a particular library

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
### Bug description

I am using a class extending BaseModel from pydantic to store some data. 

```
from pydantic import BaseModel
class Keyword(BaseModel):
    foo: str
    bar: int
```
Pylint gives a too-few-public-methods warning since the class does not have/need any public methods. So far so good. The exclude-too-few-public-methods parameter was added to alleviate exactly this problem https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/3370, but it doesn't work.

I have tried putting it in the pyproject.toml 
```
[tool.pylint]
exclude-too-few-public-methods="pydantic.*"
```

I have tried putting it in a .pylintrc
```
[DESIGN]
exclude-too-few-public-methods=pydantic.*
```

I have tried using it with CLI
```
pylint keyword.py --exclude-too-few-public-methods "pydantic.*"
```

I tried `pydantic.*` , `"pydantic.*"` , `[pydantic.*]`, `["pydantic.*"]`, `"[pydantic.*]"`, `pydantic.main.BaseModel`, `BaseModel`, `Keyword`. It just doesn't work

Either I am severely misunderstanding the documentation, which unfortunately only gives 
```
[tool.pylint.design]
exclude-too-few-public-methods = []
``` 
as an example, or the parameter is just ignored by pylint.

### Configuration

```ini
[MASTER]
extension-pkg-whitelist=pydantic
```


### Command used

```shell
pylint keyword.py
```


### Pylint output

```shell
************* Module bank_transactions_classifier.app.keyword
keyword.py:18:4: R0903: Too few public methods (0/2) (too-few-public-methods)
```


### Expected behavior

-------------------------------------------------------------------
Your code has been rated at 10.00/10 (previous run: 7.33/10, +2.67)

### Pylint version

```shell
pylint 2.14.5
astroid 2.11.7
Python 3.8.10 (v3.8.10:3d8993a744, May  3 2021, 08:55:58)
[Clang 6.0 (clang-600.0.57)]

Note i also tried pylint==2.12.0 where the feature was added
```


### OS / Environment

MacOs 10.15.7 

### Additional dependencies

pydantic==1.9.1
